text.p: ** BIRTHDAYS **
Flamboyant Scotsman ROBERT CAMPBELL was born in 1769.

Campbell arrived in Sydney in 1800 and built a famous storehouse. He was arrested during the Rum Rebellion, and went to England to testify on behalf of Captain BLIGH. He settled finally near Canberra, and his property was taken over by the Government in 1910. The land is now the site of Duntroon Military College.

Explorer CHARLES STURT, who named the Murray River, was born in 1795. STurt also took a boat and a sailor overland from Adelaide in search of the "Inland Sea", but all he found were a few small waterholes around Coopers Creek.
American actor LIONEL BARRYMORE was born in 1878.
Swedish born actress ANN-MARGRET was born in 1941. Her films include "Tommy", and "Carnal Knowledge".

African activist KENNETH KAUNDA was born in 1924. Kaunda was imprisoned in Northern Rhodesia for founding the Zambian African National Congress. He later became President of an indep*ndent Zambia, and lent assistance and asylum to members of the South African ANC.
U.S. drummer and singer with 'Dr Hook' JOHN WOLTERS was born in 1945.
Multi-instrumentalist EDWIN JOBSON was born in 1955. He has played with BRYAN FERRY, 'Roxy Music', 'Jethro Tull' and 'U.K.'. ** EVENTS **
1789 : The Mutiny on the Bounty. While transporting

breadfruit to the Society Islands, Captain WILLIAM BLIGH and 18 of his officers were cast adrift from the Bounty in a small boat by his crew lead by FLETCHER CHRISTIAN. CHRISTIAN and his men made their way back to Tahiti, while Bligh managed to get his small group to Batavia. Popular folklore has always claimed BLIGH's excessive cruelty started the Mutiny, but recent evidence suggests the incident was sparked more by the ambitions of CHRISTIAN. BLIGH's voyage to Batavia is considered one of
the all time greatest feats of seamanship.
1919 : The victorious Allies imposed the Treaty of
Versailles on Germany after the First World War. The treaty imposed huge payments on Germany, which bankrupted the country and provided the breeding ground for Hitler and the Nazis.
1945 : Italian dictator BENITO MUSSOLINI and his
mistress were captured by Italian partisans and shot. The body of the "Il Duce" was hung upside down outside a service station. 1963 : Off the West Australian coast, skin divers surfaced
with fistfuls of coins after finding the wreck of the Dutch ship "Vergulde Draeck". The ship went down in 1656.
1969 : CHARLES DE GAULLE resigned as French President
after voters rejected his proposals for changes in regional government.
1987 : American Real Estate agents arrived in London
trying to sell back London Bridge to the British. The bridge had been bought 18 years before by oil tycoon ROBERT McCULLOCH who mistook it for the Tower Bridge.
1987 : Australia's DICK SMITH became the first person to
reach the North Pole by a solo helicopter flight.
1987 : An Australian study revealed that 53 percent of
married women with children were in the paid workforce.
1996 : 28-year-old MARTIN BRYANT fatally shot 35 people

and injured many others at the Port Arthur Historic site in Tasmania, south east of Hobart. BRYANT pleaded guilty to the murders, and is is serving life sentences in Hobart's Risdon Prison. The massacre brought about new national gunlaws in Australia.
